Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 211, \u00a7\u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Brockton District Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 211, §§ 3 and 4, and the local court rules because the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Brockton and the amount in controversy falls within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence and apportionment of fault);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, \u00a7 2A.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, § 2A (applicable statute of limitations for personal actions) — noting this action is timely brought within applicable limitations;

Johnson v. Boston, 434 Mass. 99 (2001).proposition: - Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court precedent recognizing duties of proprietors/occupiers and liability for inadequate supervision and dangerous conditions on premises, including but not limited to: Johnson v. Boston, 434 Mass. 99 (2001) (example of municipal/proprietor duty principles); Strahan v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 386 Mass. 21 (1982); Dodd v. Chicopee, 341 Mass. 394 (1960); Bussiere v. Old Colony R.R., 384 Mass. 585 (1981); Kosim v. Legacy, 443 Mass. 636 (2005); and other negligence decisions addressing duty and breach (see listing of authorities below).
Johnson v. Boston, 434 Mass. 99 (2001).case_name: Western Massachusetts Lifecare Corp. v. Board of Assessors
Johnson v. Boston, 434 Mass. 99 (2001).support_reasoning: This opinion is a tax case about whether a continuing care retirement community qualifies for a charitable property tax exemption and whether the property was overvalued. It does not address tort duties of proprietors/occupiers, premises liability, supervision, or dangerous conditions on property. Citing Johnson v. Boston, 434 Mass. 99 (2001) as authority for municipal/proprietor duty principles or general negligence duty/breach is inaccurate; its holdings concern charitable exemption standards and valuation burdens, not premises liability.
Johnson v. Boston, 434 Mass. 99 (2001).relevant_excerpt: “Western contends that Reeds Landing serves a charitable purpose, namely, the provision of housing and health care to the elderly in a setting that offers them independence, dignity, and security. The provision of health care has been recognized as a traditional charitable purpose… However, the operation of Reeds Landing fails a critical component of our tests for charitable exemption from property taxes, namely, that the persons who are to benefit must be ‘of a sufficiently large or indefinite class so that the community is benefited by its operations.’”

Strahan v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 386 M.raw_text: Strahan v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 386 Mass. 21 (1982)
Strahan v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 386 M.proposition: - Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court precedent recognizing duties of proprietors/occupiers and liability for inadequate supervision and dangerous conditions on premises, including but not limited to: Johnson v. Boston, 434 Mass. 99 (2001) (example of municipal/proprietor duty principles); Strahan v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 386 Mass. 21 (1982); Dodd v. Chicopee, 341 Mass. 394 (1960); Bussiere v. Old Colony R.R., 384 Mass. 585 (1981); Kosim v. Legacy, 443 Mass. 636 (2005); and other negligence decisions addressing duty and breach (see listing of authorities below).
Strahan v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 386 M.support_reasoning: This decision is a criminal case about the voluntariness of a juvenile defendant’s confession, admissibility of evidence, psychiatric testimony, jury issues, and related procedural matters. It does not address premises liability, duties of proprietors/occupiers, supervision of premises, or negligence standards for dangerous conditions on land. Therefore it does not support the stated proposition regarding Massachusetts proprietor/occupier duties.
Strahan v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 386 M.relevant_excerpt: The case throughout concerns issues of Miranda warnings, voluntariness of statements, psychiatric evidence on criminal responsibility, jury contamination, and the validity of a search warrant. There is no discussion of duties of landowners, occupiers, or proprietors regarding supervision or dangerous conditions on premises.

Dodd v. Chicopee, 341 Mass. 394 (1960).proposition: - Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court precedent recognizing duties of proprietors/occupiers and liability for inadequate supervision and dangerous conditions on premises, including but not limited to: Johnson v. Boston, 434 Mass. 99 (2001) (example of municipal/proprietor duty principles); Strahan v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 386 Mass. 21 (1982); Dodd v. Chicopee, 341 Mass. 394 (1960); Bussiere v. Old Colony R.R., 384 Mass. 585 (1981); Kosim v. Legacy, 443 Mass. 636 (2005); and other negligence decisions addressing duty and breach (see listing of authorities below).
Dodd v. Chicopee, 341 Mass. 394 (1960).support_reasoning: This case concerns enforcement of an antenuptial agreement, the scope of an executor’s power to compromise claims, fiduciary duty, and the availability of equitable and declaratory relief. It does not involve premises liability, duties of proprietors or occupiers, inadequate supervision, or dangerous conditions on land. Citing Dodd v. Chicopee for general proprietor/occupier duty principles is therefore inaccurate and out of context.
Dodd v. Chicopee, 341 Mass. 394 (1960).relevant_excerpt: “The executor’s discretion under this power was a very broad one… It cannot properly be exercised, however, dishonestly, arbitrarily, in bad faith, or as the result of fraud. The power should be used only after serious and responsible consideration… In alleging… Esther’s appearance in opposition to the probate of Louis’s will… and… her actual receipt of such payments, the plaintiffs have stated circumstances which, if proved, would justify the conclusions that her actions were inconsistent with the antenuptial agreement and done with knowledge of what might be concluded to be a breach of the executor’s fiduciary duty.”

Bussiere v. Old Colony R.R., 384 Mass. 5.raw_text: Bussiere v. Old Colony R.R., 384 Mass. 585 (1981)
Bussiere v. Old Colony R.R., 384 Mass. 5.proposition: - Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court precedent recognizing duties of proprietors/occupiers and liability for inadequate supervision and dangerous conditions on premises, including but not limited to: Johnson v. Boston, 434 Mass. 99 (2001) (example of municipal/proprietor duty principles); Strahan v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 386 Mass. 21 (1982); Dodd v. Chicopee, 341 Mass. 394 (1960); Bussiere v. Old Colony R.R., 384 Mass. 585 (1981); Kosim v. Legacy, 443 Mass. 636 (2005); and other negligence decisions addressing duty and breach (see listing of authorities below).
Bussiere v. Old Colony R.R., 384 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: This decision is a criminal homicide appeal focused on evidentiary rulings, sequestration of witnesses, speedy trial, suppression of evidence, and related trial issues. It does not address premises liability, duties of proprietors/occupiers, supervision of persons on premises, or dangerous property conditions. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the negligence-based duty principles described in the proposition and is mis-cited for that purpose.
Bussiere v. Old Colony R.R., 384 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: On January 19, 1973, without a warrant, the police seized from the defendant’s apartment at 154 Washington Street, a milk carton containing, among other things, the nails that were matched to those in the frame of the closet where the body was found. The defendant’s motion to suppress these nails was denied on the grounds that the defendant had abandoned the premises, that the police had obtained valid consent to be on the premises, and that the defendant lacked standing to contest the search and seizure.

Kosim v. Legacy, 443 Mass. 636 (2005).proposition: - Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court precedent recognizing duties of proprietors/occupiers and liability for inadequate supervision and dangerous conditions on premises, including but not limited to: Johnson v. Boston, 434 Mass. 99 (2001) (example of municipal/proprietor duty principles); Strahan v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 386 Mass. 21 (1982); Dodd v. Chicopee, 341 Mass. 394 (1960); Bussiere v. Old Colony R.R., 384 Mass. 585 (1981); Kosim v. Legacy, 443 Mass. 636 (2005); and other negligence decisions addressing duty and breach (see listing of authorities below).
Kosim v. Legacy, 443 Mass. 636 (2005).support_reasoning: This decision concerns judicial estoppel, not premises liability or duties of proprietors/occupiers to supervise or maintain safe conditions. The court analyzes whether Otis is barred from asserting a litigation position inconsistent with his prior successful position; it does not discuss or establish any principles about landowner or proprietor duties, supervision, or dangerous conditions on premises. Citing Kosim v. Legacy for such a duty/breach proposition is therefore inaccurate.
Kosim v. Legacy, 443 Mass. 636 (2005).relevant_excerpt: “Judicial estoppel is an equitable doctrine that precludes a party from asserting a position in one legal proceeding that is contrary to a position it had previously asserted in another proceeding. … The purpose of the doctrine is to prevent the manipulation of the judicial process by litigants.” (443 Mass. at 640).
